meta.title: Putin's Propaganda Machine: Soft Power and Russian Foreign Policy
meta.author: Marcel H. Van Herpen

parts.title: Introduction to Russia's Propaganda Tactics
parts.body: Introduction: This section sheds light on the Russian propaganda machinery during the 2014 Ukraine Conflict. It parallels the Soviet disinformation tactics of the past, highlighting how it mixes truths, half truths, and falsehoods effectively. Precedent from the Soviet era like Lenin and the KGB's operations is drawn to depict the evolution of information control under Putin. With an emphasis on modern media usage, it elaborates crucial shifts in tactics and cites real world examples of their implications while warning about challenges to Western public perception.

parts.title: Russia's Information War and Propaganda Tactics
parts.body:
Russia's Information War and Propaganda Tactics

Igor Panarin presents a conspiracy theory suggesting that the Soviet Union's fall stemmed from a Western secret plan, labeling it the "First Global Information War." According to Panarin, countries like the US and UK orchestrated this to damage the USSR, starting in 1943. He alleges that Nikita Khrushchev and Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership were part of this operation, facilitated by Western secret agencies. This narrative reflects a broader belief in a Western conspiracy in Russian thought, illustrated in Panarin and Aleksandr Dugin’s works, the latter of whom depicts a world caught in mystical conspiracies. Russia reinterprets post-Soviet events as a periodic continuation of this supposed information warfare. Efforts to enhance domestic control and propaganda abroad, like funding RT and launching channels in various languages, are viewed as part of a defensive strategy. Panarin foresees the "second information war" concluding with a Russian triumph if the political elite engage in an "uncompromising informational-psychological" conflict. Consequently, since 2012, Putin has enhanced media control and restricted NGOs, perpetuating a narrative against foreign "negative information flows."

parts.title: Russia's Soft-Power Strategy Revealed
parts.body: The chapter outlines Russia's "soft-power offensive," focusing on three strategies: 1. Mimesis: Russia mirrors Western soft-power tactics, creating organizations similar to Freedom House, like the Institute for Democracy and Cooperation (IDC). These entities promote Russia's view on democracy and human rights, often contrasting Western values. 2. Rollback: This involves reducing Western influence inside Russia by limiting activities of Western soft-power institutions. Russia sets up bodies like Rossotrudnichestvo and Russkiy Mir to project its power, especially within the former Soviet Union, and focus on geopolitical clout rather than cultural exchange. 3. Invention: This includes crafting novel strategies that exploit Western openness. Tactics range from public relations campaigns to covert operations, mimicking past KGB techniques for a broader global influence.

parts.title: International Expansion of Russian Cultural Centers
parts.body: Russkiy Mir sees "Russian World" as a global community, including ethnic Russians, Russian speakers, and Orthodox believers worldwide. It sets up Russian centers in universities abroad, resembling China's Confucius Institutes. Like Confucius Institutes, these centers on campuses aim to expand influence but with ties to Russian government interests. Critics raise concerns about such centers, saying they could foster propaganda and limit academic freedom. Unlike other Western cultural diplomacy organizations, these Russian initiatives are directly tied to the government and have political motives.

parts.title: Soviet Propaganda Tactics and Their Evolution
parts.body: The text discusses Kremlin's propaganda tactics used previously during the Soviet era and how they evolved post-fall of communism. Back then, overt propaganda involved mediums like Radio Moscow, Soviet magazines, and colorful stories about Soviet achievements. However, it mostly reached those already sympathetic to the Soviet cause. Covert propaganda had more hidden avenues like front organizations that appeared non-communist to hide the Soviet connection. Meanwhile, "fellow travelers"—intellectuals who were not communists but showed naivety towards the regime—also disseminated propaganda. Notable examples include George Bernard Shaw and Sydney & Beatrice Webb, who praised the Soviet regime despite its flaws. This was principally a time when Soviet propaganda had limited access to Western media. However, after the collapse of communism, this scenario changed. Russia's conversion to capitalism and democracy altered its global image, allowing greater media access. This change meant that while Russia did not become a completely friendly power, it did gain a significant foothold within Western media, unlike during the communist era. Consequently, this established a more normalized international presence.

parts.title: Russia's Soft Power and RT Influence
parts.body: Russia increased use of "soft power" by leveraging various tools, such as propaganda and media influence. During the Soviet-era, their power relied heavily on military might, but today, Russia is utilizing its cultural and historical ties with neighboring countries and Russian-language communities. The Kremlin also contracted Western PR firms and organized major conferences to influence foreign opinion. This was part of a broader propaganda strategy to shape its international image and actively engage in the Western media landscape. The launch of the Russia Today (RT) English channel exemplifies this push into global media. From its inception, RT sought to challenge prominent networks like CNN and BBC. Despite its official affiliation, RT presented itself with diverse and often controversial content, which included anti-US rhetoric and promotion of conspiracy theories. The channel invited extreme viewpoints and was achieved a significant presence online and on YouTube. This massive investment is indicative of Russia's determination to use media as an instrument for influence, aiming to reshape perceptions and drive a wedge between Europe and the USA over conflicts such as those in Ukraine. RT serves as an impressive example of contemporary propaganda, presenting news heavily slanted to serve Russian state interests.

parts.title: Russian Influence in Western Media: The Lebedev Case
parts.body: Lebedev was a former KGB officer turned media owner, acquiring stakes in the British papers London Evening Standard and The Independent. He claimed his intention wasn't to make money but to "waste money" by supporting loss-making publications. Despite promises of editorial independence, concerns arose about his Kremlin ties, especially after he received funds directly sanctioned by Vladimir Putin. Though voted out of United Russia, he still preserved a semidissident image, backing anti-corruption efforts in Russia. Lebedev's strategy mirrored Pugachev's in France, as they both took on loss-making newspapers with the intention of building media empires. Both used a father-and-son dynamic for management. Distinctly, while Pugachev failed due to financial and editorial challenges, Lebedev managed a profit with the Evening Standard by making it a free paper, showcasing more adept management. Despite ongoing vigilance regarding Kremlin influence, Lebedev and his son became prominent figures in the British media landscape.

parts.title: Soviet Influence in Foreign Politics and Recent Infiltrations
parts.body: Soviet Influence in Foreign Politics During Soviet times, the Kremlin financially supported foreign political parties and politicians. An example is Finnish President Urho Kekkonen, who received millions from Moscow for his campaign and personal expenses. Post-Soviet Russia, although losing control over communist parties, began influencing "bourgeois" parties in the West. This approach was less visible and secretive but became effective, targeting new political systems that were not previously approachable. Recent Examples of Infiltration Hélène Blanc and Renata Lesnik highlight intensified Russian infiltration in Europe, citing a 2002 example where French candidate François Bayrou was offered a funded campaign by unknown Russians. Despite refusing, it revealed vulnerabilities in political funding regulations. Interpol warned that alongside terrorism, Europe faces threats from ex-Soviet businessmen seeking political power. Funds typically come through European banks, masking Moscow's involvement, as seen in Netherlands and France.

parts.title: Modern Russian Espionage Tactics
parts.body: Russian espionage has seen high-profile infiltration within the US and Europe, with aggressive efforts targeting officials and politicians. Russian spies often pose as diplomats or use fake identities to gather sensitive information. Back in the Soviet era, Russian embassies used a significant portion of their staff for espionage. In modern times, Russian espionage continues to be persistent and sophisticated, reflecting Cold War levels of activity, targeting post-Soviet and European states such as Estonia and the Czech Republic for valuable information.

parts.title: Kremlin & Orthodox Church Assault on Universal Human Rights
parts.body: In recent years, Russian foreign policy has increasingly integrated "traditional values," particularly against universal human rights. The Russian Orthodox Church (ROC) and the Kremlin have worked closely, attacking human rights in various international forums. They argue that such rights should be implemented with respect to cultural specificities. This has sparked debates regarding controversial issues like reproductive rights and LGBT rights. The ROC's critique formalized in a 2008 document emphasizes that human rights shouldn't override religious traditions, leading to strategic movements in UN meetings to promote traditional values over global norms. The joint efforts between the Kremlin and the ROC aim to redefine global ideological influences towards a "Russian World," using Russkiy Mir Foundation to spread Russian culture and Orthodoxy abroad. This new strategy echoes Soviet times but targets the Russian diaspora instead of international communists, indicating a focus on nationalism and conservativism. Their efforts are most visible when defending Russian interests and countering Western ideologies in international spaces, despite significant resistance from entities like the EU and the UN Human Rights Council against restrictive practices on minority rights.

parts.title: Russian Orthodox Church and State Subordination
parts.body: Russian Orthodox Church is being used by the Kremlin for soft-power influence, spreading neoimperialist ideology. It lacks independence from the state, failing to be a moral authority due to its history of subordination to state power. This subservience hinders its role as a universal standard-bearer of morality or human rights. Historically, this connection to state power has distorted its moral influence, as seen during Chechen conflicts. The ROC also stood by during the Maidan revolt in Ukraine, aligning with state views rather than upholding independent moral standing.

parts.title: The ROC's Restrictive Role in Religious Freedom
parts.body: The Russian Orthodox Church (ROC) is characterized by a profound illiberal ideology, mostly reserving religious freedom for itself, and actively working to restrict it for other denominations. Post-Soviet attempts by the ROC to limit new religious entrants highlighted its opposition to religious pluralism. This stance gained momentum with Russia's government and intelligence agencies, which framed foreign missionaries as agents of espionage. By 1997, a new law discriminatory to "minority religions" like Protestantism and Catholicism was enacted, enforcing stringent registration processes that marginalized and criminalized groups like the Salvation Army and Jehovah’s Witnesses under the guise of combating extremism.

parts.title: German Political Elite's Pro-Russian Sentiment
parts.body: German elites, especially politicians and media, show significant tolerance towards Russia's hardline politics, possibly due to historical guilt over WWII. Former SPD Chancellor Gerhard Schröder exemplifies the pro-Russian sentiment; he maintains a close friendship with Putin, highlighted by personal interventions. After his political career, Schröder controversially took a role with Nord Stream, a Gazprom project, provoking criticism for potential conflict of interest. Frank-Walter Steinmeier, another key figure, is known for his pro-Kremlin stance. Promoted within Schröder's circle, he later became Foreign Minister, backing policies favorable to Russia, such as opposing Ukraine and Georgia’s NATO membership due to "frozen conflicts." This stance risked tension with Western allies, especially as it conflicted with US policies as expressed by Condoleezza Rice.

parts.title: Pro-Russia Bias in German Politics and Society
parts.body: ## Pro-Russia Bias in German Politics and Society German political figures and public attitudes have shown an inclination toward Russia-friendly policies. Largely due to historical ties and economic interdependence, this bias can be seen across the political spectrum, from the SPD (Social Democratic Party) to extreme parties on both ends. For instance, Steinmeier's calls for dialogue with Moscow often overshadowed calls for sanctions after Russian aggression. Even Chancellor Merkel found herself at odds with him at times over these issues. Nostalgia for Eastern German-Russian ties also manifests in former GDR perspectives that favor Russian alliances over Western ones. This is evident by figures like Helmut Schmidt resisting condemnation of Russia despite its aggressive moves internationally. Besides political figures, organizations like the German-Russian Forum also reflect these sentiments. Former East German leaders serve on its board, propagating friendly relations based on historical & economic engagement. This tendency echoes in businesses like E.ON Ruhrgas, showing strong ties to Russian energy through interlocking interests. Prominent figures who were once part of the East German regime have moved into roles facilitating Russo-Germanic contracts, suggesting a systematic interdependence. However, critics argue these associations often underestimate the implications of Putin’s policies and seek to downplay measures needed to uphold European security and cohesion. Such attitudes risk reinforcing Russia's geopolitical ambitions at the expense of broader European unity.

parts.title: German-Russian Relations Impact on Foreign Policy
parts.body: German-Government Influence: Germany's relations with Russia have impacted its foreign policy, particularly with the US, NATO, and Eastern Europe. Chancellor Schröder weakened ties with the US by adopting a "Russia first" strategy, which led to criticism. This ambivalence continued under Angela Merkel, causing tensions with NATO, as Germany protested against US proposals like NATO Membership Action Plans for Ukraine and Georgia. European Concerns: Germany's potential shift toward Russia worries Eastern Europe. Historical tensions with Poland and other neighbors may rekindle due to Germany's military collaboration with Russia, reminiscent of past cooperation in the 1920s. This closeness with Russia undermines its role as a reliable partner for the US and EU, highlighting a risks of loosening ties with Western countries.

parts.title: France-Russia Relations: Evolving Strategic Partnership
parts.body: The relationship between France and Russia has evolved, showcasing a mutual friendship that began under Chirac and continued with Sarkozy. Despite initial concerns regarding human rights in Russia during the Chechnya conflict, France pursued stronger ties with Moscow during the Iraq war, aligning against the US intervention. The partnership deepened with the awarding of orders like the Légion d’honneur to Putin, sparking controversy. Under Sarkozy, despite his initial stance on human rights, French diplomacy leaned towards practical relations with Russia. The Mistral deal exemplified this partnership, marking a significant arms sale from a NATO country to Russia. This sale drew criticism from other NATO allies like Poland due to the sale's potential impact on European security. In the diplomatic sphere, France pursued an EU-Russia security collaboration, which alarmed diplomats by seeming to detach from the traditional US-EU alliance. Sarkozy's administration, while acknowledging global security intricacies, sought to align France more closely with Moscow's strategic interests, symbolizing a larger shift in European geopolitical dynamics.

parts.title: The Kremlin’s Influence in France and Europe
parts.body: The Kremlin has made notable progress in improving its image, despite *aggression* in Ukraine straining relations with France, especially under socialist President François Hollande. Initially more skeptical than Sarkozy, Hollande still maintained economic cooperation with Russia, signaling a pragmatic approach. Putin’s personal diplomacy, combined with economic ties through French energy giant Total and think tank IFRI’s indirect influence, illustrated how deeply embedded Russia’s ties were with French political and business elites. This alliance complicated the EU's response to Russia’s actions, highlighting how deeply financial and strategic interests were entwined. Russian soft power efforts expanded beyond France, aiming for a strategic Berlin-Moscow-Paris triangle to counter U.S. influence in Europe. This strategy leveraged sympathetic political parties, particularly in extreme political spectrums, showing Russia’s attempts to shape European geopolitics by forging alliances and sympathies across political divides. Ideological admiration and financial ties further reinforced Russia’s influence, even as EU nations sought to balance strategic interests against growing concerns over Russia's revisionist tendencies.

parts.title: Combating Propaganda and Trolls
parts.body: Lithuania and Latvia have taken steps to limit Russian media following propaganda accusations, such as banning NTV Mir and suspending Rossiya RTR. Countries like Estonia prefer counter-programming over strict bans to combat this media influence, producing content in their local languages instead. The Kremlin employs online trolls to spread pro-Kremlin messages, often causing chaos in internet forums. Papers like the Moscow Times have disabled comment sections due to such disruptive activity. Recognizing these trolls can be challenging, yet blacklists could serve as a solution. Western governments might consider agencies dedicated to identifying and addressing Kremlin's digital misinformation.

parts.title: Russian Orthodox Church and the KGB's Role in Modern Geopolitics
parts.body: The Russian Orthodox Church, acting as a global church, has substantial relations with the KGB, which historically included a coup d'état and the First Chief Directorate of KGB. Patrick Johnstone and Metropolitan Anthony appear within this network, emphasizing the church's expansive links and influences over time. On a geopolitical note, Kaliningrad is crucial, hosting military exercises like Kavkaz-2012. Leaders such as Kadyrov, Patriarch Kirill, and entities like LukOil remind us of Russia's political and energy power plays. The KGB’s influence extends beyond traditional espionage, impacting modern political and religious narratives, illustrating a blend of politics, religion, and energy in Russian strategic maneuvering.

parts.title: Key Personalities and Political Dynamics
parts.body: ## Key Personalities and Political Dynamics Moisés Naím emerges as an influential figure, while different political parties such as the National Bolshevik Party and Nashi make their presence felt. The intricacy of nationalism in both its historical and Russian contexts is apparent as it interweaves through alliances like the National Reserve Bank and other entities. Organizations such as NGOs—focused both on American influence and those restricted in Russia—highlight ongoing tensions. Figures like Aleksey Navalny and Nursultan Nazarbayev stand out as part of the broader political landscape.
